text: Canada is so bad for this. I know horizontal distances in meters / kilometres, but vertical distances in feet. I know small weights in grams, people level weights in feet and vehicle level weights in kilograms. I know volumes in litres unless it’s to do with cooking, then it’s cups and spoons. I know outdoor temperatures in Celsius, but oven temperatures in Fahrenheit.

elements.text: Canada is so bad for this. I know horizontal distances in meters / kilometres, but vertical distances in feet. I know small weights in grams, people level weights in feet and vehicle level weights in kilograms. I know volumes in litres unless it’s to do with cooking, then it’s cups and spoons. I know outdoor temperatures in Celsius, but oven temperatures in Fahrenheit.

text:
Also a lot of imperial measures being convenient sizes for humans.

and half a liter is a decent drink.

text:
I think the reason Fahrenheit is so hard is because its not linear tranform of Celsius, it’s affine.
I can remember 1 multiplication.
But 2 numbers and two operations? too hard

elements.text:

text:
>  Metric is obviously great for KG/M/L since it makes conversion so much easier. For temperature though, you don’t ever need to convert on a day to day basis
It doesn’t hit the same niceness.
Like a pendulumn on a 1 meter string changes direction once per second
1 Kg of water occupies 1L
Move 1 kg  1m by expending 10J

But it is 4,200 J to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water by 1°C.

elements.text: Metric is obviously great for KG/M/L since it makes conversion so much easier. For temperature though, you don’t ever need to convert on a day to day basis

It doesn’t hit the same niceness.
Like a pendulumn on a 1 meter string changes direction once per second
1 Kg of water occupies 1L
Move 1 kg  1m by expending 10J

But it is 4,200 J to raise the temperature of 1 kg of water by 1°C.

text:
This is useful when you want to compare how hot it is outside to how much you weigh. I know I weigh around 80kg, but how do I know if that's a lot compared to the ambient air temperature?
```using NaturallyUnitful
natural(80u"kg")

#+RESULTS:
: 4.487670883043562e37 eV```
Ah, I see I weigh a lot.

elements.text: This is useful when you want to compare how hot it is outside to how much you weigh. I know I weigh around 80kg, but how do I know if that's a lot compared to the ambient air temperature?

using NaturallyUnitful
natural(80u"kg")

#+RESULTS:
: 4.487670883043562e37 eV
Ah, I see I weigh a lot.

text: Natural Units are ambiguous

elements.text: Natural Units are ambiguous

text: They are in fact perfectly unambigious. It's an accident of human history and circumstance that you think time and space or energy and temperature need different units.

elements.text: They are in fact perfectly unambigious. It's an accident of human history and circumstance that you think time and space or energy and temperature need different units.

text: (Note however that setting G=1 would introduce an ambiguity though if you did it simultaneously with hbar=1, so you shouldn’t use ‘NaturalGeometrizedUnits’)

elements.text: (Note however that setting G=1 would introduce an ambiguity though if you did it simultaneously with hbar=1, so you shouldn’t use ‘NaturalGeometrizedUnits’)

text: The half-assed embrace of the SI system happens in my country too. In Colombia you buy gasoline in gallons, a lot of the construction measurements are in inches and feet, among many others. It's so annoying. At least temperatures and distances are always SI.

elements.text: The half-assed embrace of the SI system happens in my country too. In Colombia you buy gasoline in gallons, a lot of the construction measurements are in inches and feet, among many others. It's so annoying. At least temperatures and distances are always SI.

text:
I will die on the hill that Fahrenheit is a better temperature scale for exactly the reasons that <@U0179G7FG4F> gave:
- it’s % of hotness from a human perspective
- the deciles work beautifully to describe rough blocks of temperatures with good intuitive descriptions: 0-10 extremely cold, 10-20 very cold, 20-30 really cold, 30-40 cold, 40-50 chilly, 50-60 cool, 60-70 pleasant, 70-80 warm, 80-90 hot, 90-100 very hot
- the size of a degree is reasonable: Celsius is like a volume knob where the from one level is too quiet and then very next level is way too loud; Fahrenheit, is a volume knob where there’s always a level that’s just what you’re looking for

elements.text: I will die on the hill that Fahrenheit is a better temperature scale for exactly the reasons that

gave:
- it’s % of hotness from a human perspective
- the deciles work beautifully to describe rough blocks of temperatures with good intuitive descriptions: 0-10 extremely cold, 10-20 very cold, 20-30 really cold, 30-40 cold, 40-50 chilly, 50-60 cool, 60-70 pleasant, 70-80 warm, 80-90 hot, 90-100 very hot
- the size of a degree is reasonable: Celsius is like a volume knob where the from one level is too quiet and then very next level is way too loud; Fahrenheit, is a volume knob where there’s always a level that’s just what you’re looking for
